title: Victorian Era Typefaces
content:
Hey everyone, I'm doing a project involving Vaudeville and looking to incorporate Victorian Era faces.

I know a lot of these aren't digitized, but can anyone identify any of the faces in these images which I scanned from an 1898 city directory?

I've attached these as image links, so sorry for the inconvenice, I can't seem to upload images with the new maximum file size (anyone know what it is by the way? I can't even squeak in tiny little .gif files) and can't link either :(

Anyways, here are the links for anyone willing to cut and paste them:

[http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography1.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography1.jpg "http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography1.jpg")  
 [http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography2.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography2.jpg "http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography2.jpg")  
 [http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography3.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography3.jpg "http://studentpages.scad.edu/~jschul23/typography3.jpg")

Thanks so much!
author: jschul23

comments.content: ' [Beaumarchais](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.fontcraft.com/scriptorium/previews/beaumarchais.jpg)' _( [Scriptorium](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.fontcraft.com/scriptorium/) )_ may be close enough for 'Train & Harty' + 'Insurance'..

[P22](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.p22.com/products/index.html) has a search by period. Could be incredibly useful.

May I recommend [P22 Kilkenny](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.p22.com/ihof/kilkenny.html)
Ok. I thought I was in the DESIGN section. I need to make the type larger for my eyes. ehehe. Sorry. P22 might still have something though.

Oh, And, ' [Paydirt](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.csaimages.com/results.asp?image=FNT017&wwwflag=2&imagepos=17)' _( [CSA Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.csaimages.com/) )_ may get you close to 'Broughton Street'..

TRAIN & HARTY and INSURANCE used a typeface called Columbus Bold. Beaumarchais is a digitization of Columbus (not bold). The only digital version of Columbus Bold I know of is Brendel Informatik's [Columbus](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.qbf.de/cart/cart.exe?gif=tc.gif/Stc02155.gif).

'Civil Engineer and Architect' was done, I think, in a typeface called Obelisk. I'm not aware of any digital versions, though.

Alternatives might be Letterhead Fonts' digitization of Asteroid which they call [LHF Ambrosia](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/letterheadfonts.com/downloads/index.shtml). This is squared and upright like Obelisk, but perhaps too heavy. A font with a similar weight, but fancier, would be [Jugend WF](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.waldenfont.com/content.asp?contentpageID=10) from Walden Fonts.

Ooohh, just discovered the nearly new Solotype offering [Sentry](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/sentry/sentry/testdrive.html?s=Civil+Engineer+and+Architect&p=48). A much better alternative to Obelisk.

looks like there's a bit of [DeVinne Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/woodentypefonts/de-vinne/italic) in there... i'll take a closer look when i have more time...

Thnx for the plug, Miss Tiff! ;^)

Interesting... that's different from the De Vinne Italic I know

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-italic/win-ttf/1...](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-italic/win-ttf/140902/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-italic/win-ttf/140902/")

You will find tons of Victorian fonts in the [Solotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20120104164104/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=solotype&itemsperpage=100&resultcount=125&page=1) library

Wow. Now here's synchronicity at work; regards the typography.3.jpg - last week a student called Minna Pesonen left samples reproduced from a 1906 newspaper featuring the very same typeface on my desk, with a request to please identify the headline type.

Although I looked for it myself in various references (including the very Victorian Typographical Volume, Early Advertising Art by Clarence Hornung) to no avail, I also directed her to this site, but without realising this particular face was already under discussion.

Looks like Columbus Bold/Beaumarchais is about to enjoy a resurgence in popularity...!
